prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 2-1 z~1.2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO 2-1 observations of the two targets at z~1.17

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: We computed indirect measures of the total H2 content of our selected galaxies using the method described in Popping et al. (2012). Applying a conservative value for the conversion between H2 mass and CO intensity (alpha_CO = 3.6 [M_sun/(K km s^-1 pc^2)]) we obtained a CO J=1-0 flux estimate. Assuming an observed line-width of 400 km s^-1, typical for star-forming galaxies at these redshifts (Tacconi et al. 2010, Genzel et al. 2010) we obtain a CO J=1-0 peak flux density of 1.95 mJy for the faintest of the two sources at z~1.17. We adopted a conservative value for the conversion between CO and H2 mass. Changing this to values generally used for typical star-forming galaxies at z=1.2 (alpha_CO = 3.2 [M_sun/(K km s^-1 pc^2)]; Tacconi et al. 2010, Genzel et al. 2010, Tacconi et al. 2013), will only increase our estimates for the peak flux densities.
Assuming the objects of interest have molecular gas excitation conditions similar to the Milky Way ISM (Tkin = 25 K and molecular cloud density of n = 1300 cm^âˆ’3), we calculate the line-ratio between CO J=2-1 and CO J=1-0. To secure a strong signal we compute our required sensitivities and integration times imposing a signal-to-noise of S/N =7. The required sensitivity for CO J=2-1 imposing signal-to-noise ratio of S/N = 7 is rms = 1.77 mJy(see table 2 in the scientific justification). A Milky Way excitation condition again is a very conservative scenario. If the cold gas in the observed galaxies is much denser, we expect the CO line-ratios to increase leading to a high peak flux density.
A window is placed in band 3 to observe CO J=2-1 at z~1.17 (sky frequency of 106.18 GHz). We will use the most compact configuration array C32-1, dual polarization, a band-width of 1875 MHz and resolution of 976.562 kHz. We will not resolve our targets spatially, as the necessary UV coverage would increase the necessary observing time dramatically, whereas a secure detection of the line-profiles of our galaxies is sufficient to meet our science goals. The chosen band-width secures that the full line-profile of the galaxies falls within one observation. The expected line profile widths are 400 km s^-1 and to resolve the line profiles a resolution of 50 km s^-1 is sufficient.
We calculated the continuum emission of our objects assuming that the continuum radiation is caused by dust at a temperature of 30 K (typical for star-forming galaxies) emitting its radiation as a grey body.
The expected observing time for the two objects including calibration and overheads for this science goal is ~ 28 minutes.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 3-2 z~2.3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO 3-2 observations for two objects at CO 2.3

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: We computed indirect measures of the total H2 content of our selected galaxies using the method described in Popping et al. (2012). Applying a conservative value for the conversion between H2 mass and CO intensity (alpha_CO = 3.6 [M_sun/(K km s^-1 pc^2)]) we obtained a CO J=1-0 flux estimate. Assuming an observed line-width of 400 km s^-1, typical for star-forming galaxies at these redshifts (Tacconi et al. 2010, Genzel et al. 2010) we obtain a CO J=1-0 peak flux density of 0.75 mJy for the faintest of the two sources at z~2.3. We adopted a conservative value for the conversion between CO and H2 mass. Changing this to values generally used for typical star-forming galaxies at z=2.2 (alpha_CO = 3.2 [M_sun/(K km s^-1 pc^2)]; Tacconi et al. 2010, Genzel et al. 2010, Tacconi et al. 2013), will only increase our estimates for the peak flux densities.
Assuming the objects of interest have molecular gas excitation conditions similar to the Milky Way ISM (Tkin = 25 K and molecular cloud density of n = 1300 cm^âˆ’3), we calculate the line-ratio between CO J=3-2 and CO J=1-0. To secure a strong signal we compute our required sensitivities and integration times imposing a signal-to-noise of S/N =7. The required sensitivity for CO J=3-2 imposing signal-to-noise ratio of S/N = 7 is rms = 1.29 mJy(see table 2 in the scientific justification). A Milky Way excitation condition again is a very conservative scenario. If the cold gas in the observed galaxies is much denser, we expect the CO line-ratios to increase leading to a high peak flux density.
A window is placed in band 3 to observe CO J=3-2 at z~2.3 (sky frequency of 100.34 GHz). We will use the most compact configuration array C32-1, dual polarization, a band-width of 1875 MHz and resolution of 976.562 kHz. We will not resolve our targets spatially, as the necessary UV coverage would increase the necessary observing time dramatically, whereas a secure detection of the line-profiles of our galaxies is sufficient to meet our science goals. The chosen band-width secures that the full line-profile of the galaxies falls within one observation. The expected line profile widths are 400 km s^-1 and to resolve the line profiles a resolution of 50 km s^-1 is sufficient.
We calculated the continuum emission of our objects assuming that the continuum radiation is caused by dust at a temperature of 30 K (typical for star-forming galaxies) emitting its radiation as a grey body.
The expected observing time for the two objects including calibration and overheads for this science goal is ~ 57 minutes.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO 3-2 z~1.2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO 3-2 observations for two objects at z~1.2

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: We computed indirect measures of the total H2 content of our selected galaxies using the method described in Popping et al. (2012). Applying a conservative value for the conversion between H2 mass and CO intensity (alpha_CO = 3.6 [M_sun/(K km s^-1 pc^2)]) we obtained a CO J=1-0 flux estimate. Assuming an observed line-width of 400 km s^-1, typical for star-forming galaxies at these redshifts (Tacconi et al. 2010, Genzel et al. 2010) we obtain a CO J=1-0 peak flux density of 1.95 mJy for the faintest of the two sources at z~1.17. We adopted a conservative value for the conversion between CO and H2 mass. Changing this to values generally used for typical star-forming galaxies at z=1.2 (alpha_CO = 3.2 [M_sun/(K km s^-1 pc^2)]; Tacconi et al. 2010, Genzel et al. 2010, Tacconi et al. 2013), will only increase our estimates for the peak flux densities.
Assuming the objects of interest have molecular gas excitation conditions similar to the Milky Way ISM (Tkin = 25 K and molecular cloud density of n = 1300 cm^âˆ’3), we calculate the line-ratio between CO J=3-2 and CO J=1-0. To secure a strong signal we compute our required sensitivities and integration times imposing a signal-to-noise of S/N =7. The required sensitivity for CO J=3-2 imposing signal-to-noise ratio of S/N = 7 is rms = 3.36 mJy(see table 2 in the scientific justification). A Milky Way excitation condition again is a very conservative scenario. If the cold gas in the observed galaxies is much denser, we expect the CO line-ratios to increase leading to a high peak flux density.
A window is placed in band 4 to observe CO J=3-2 at z~1.17 (sky frequency of 159.3 GHz). We will use the most compact configuration array C32-1, dual polarization, a band-width of 1875 MHz and resolution of 976.562 kHz. We will not resolve our targets spatially, as the necessary UV coverage would increase the necessary observing time dramatically, whereas a secure detection of the line-profiles of our galaxies is sufficient to meet our science goals. The chosen band-width secures that the full line-profile of the galaxies falls within one observation. The expected line profile widths are 400 km s^-1 and to resolve the line profiles a resolution of 50 km s^-1 is sufficient.
We calculated the continuum emission of our objects assuming that the continuum radiation is caused by dust at a temperature of 30 K (typical for star-forming galaxies) emitting its radiation as a grey body.
The expected observing time for the two objects including calibration and overheads for this science goal is ~ 27 minutes.

Requested sensitivity: We computed indirect measures of the total H2 content of our selected galaxies using the method described in Popping et al. (2012). Applying a conservative value for the conversion between H2 mass and CO intensity (alpha_CO = 3.6 [M_sun/(K km s^-1 pc^2)]) we obtained a CO J=1-0 flux estimate. Assuming an observed line-width of 400 km s^-1, typical for star-forming galaxies at these redshifts (Tacconi et al. 2010, Genzel et al. 2010) we obtain a CO J=1-0 peak flux density of 0.75 mJy for the faintest of the two sources at z~2.3. We adopted a conservative value for the conversion between CO and H2 mass. Changing this to values generally used for typical star-forming galaxies at z=2.2 (alpha_CO = 3.2 [M_sun/(K km s^-1 pc^2)]; Tacconi et al. 2010, Genzel et al. 2010, Tacconi et al. 2013), will only increase our estimates for the peak flux densities.
Observations in our Milky Way (e.g., Israel et al. 2003) and in high-redshift sub-millimeter galaxies (Walter et al. 2011) suggest a typical [CI] 3P1-3P0 /CO J=1-0 luminosity-ratio of approximately 0.1, in good agreement with Large Velocity Gradient calculations assuming Milky Way like excitation conditions (T_kin = 25 K and molecular cloud density of n = 1300 cm^-3). To secure a strong signal we compute our required sensitivities and integration times imposing a signal-to-noise of S/N =7. Taking a ratio between carbon and CO of 0.1 in luminosity and imposing a signal-to-noise ratio of 7, the required sensitivity for the faintest source is rms = 0.64 mJy (see table 2 in the scientific justification).
A window is placed in band 4 to observe [CI] 3P1-3P0 at z~2.3 (sky frequency of 142.82 GHz). We will use the most compact configuration array C32-1, dual polarization, a band-width of 1875 MHz and resolution of 976 kHz. We will not resolve our targets spatially, as the necessary UV coverage would increase the necessary observing time dramatically, whereas a secure detection of the line-profiles of our galaxies is sufficient to meet our science goals. The chosen band-width secures that the full line-profile of the galaxies falls within one observation. The expected line profile widths are 400 km s^-1 and to resolve the line profiles a resolution of 50 km s^-1 is sufficient. We therefore compute our integration times assuming a spectral rebinning to 50 km s^-1.
We calculated the continuum emission of our objects assuming that the continuum radiation is caused by dust at a temperature of 30 K (typical for star-forming galaxies) emitting its radiation as a grey body.
The expected observing time for the two objects including calibration and overheads for this science goal is ~ 1.28 hours.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The nature of the ISM in typical star-forming galaxies during the peak in star formation (SF) activity of the Universe (z =1â€“3) is still unknown. We propose to observe CO and [CI] lines to determine the dominant physical properties (density, temperature, local radiation field, carbon abundance) of the star-forming ISM in four galaxies, two at z = 1.2 and two at z âˆ¼ 2.3. The proposed targets are typical examples of the galaxies responsible for the bulk of SF during the SF peak of the Universe. These observations will reveal whether the physical state of the ISM in such galaxies is similar to local counterparts â€“ a scaled-up version of typical nearby galaxies â€“ or is significantly different and will probe the evolution of the ISM properties in galaxies. These observations represent the first attempt towards a detailed understanding of the nature of the ISM in typical star-forming galaxies during the z = 1â€“3 SF peak.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen
